node.title: Formal definition of mesh bias parameter
node.bodyText:
I have looked for, but have been unable to find, a quantitative definition for how the mesh bias variable behaves.  Is this essentially a geometric series, where the distance between node 0 and n for n > 0 is given by:
distance = sum (a r^(n - 1) ) = a(1 - r^(n-1)) / 1 - r
where a is the first spacing (i.e. between nodes 0 and 1), r is the bias value and n is the node number?
I suspect there is a very simple explanation for this but I run into problems as there are three parameters to define in the mesh block: the number of nodes, the distance spanned and the bias value.  Does this mean that by choosing the length of a particular dimension and the number of nodes I wish to use, the bias value is fixed?  But if the geometric nature is true then one should also be able to define the first spacing, a.   The more I look at it the further away I get from understanding it!  If there is a definition on the MOOSE help pages then I would appreciate a link to it.  Many thanks in advance for the help.

Hello
Which mesh generator is this for?
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/mesh/GeneratedMesh.html ?
I looked at the code, and the a (standard spacing in the non-biased case, not the first spacing anymore) is being modified to respect the number of nodes, the bias value and the distance in that generator.
Guillaume

On a quick note we re getting more mesh biasing work in this PR. Not sure that is relevant for you
#20638

node.title: Creation of individual output files for multiapp reset times
node.bodyText:
Hi Guillaume,
You might've remember this work (#18549) which happened quite a while ago. I observed an odd thing concerning the creation of exodus outputs while working on my recent activity on QuadraturePointMultiapp. The specification of list of reset_time's given in the input enables the creation of output files for all these times which would multiply if we are using a large mesh. Is there a possibility of suppressing the creation of such files either by setting options in the input file or by other means?
[MultiApps]
  [sub]
    type = QuadraturePointMultiapp
    input_files = 'sub_gs_uniaxial_noCPFE.i'
    output_in_position = true
    execute_on = timestep_end
    reset_time = '0.02 0.03 0.04 0.05'
  []
[]



Kind regards,
Arun

Hello
You can change the amount of output by setting in the MultiApp input file (sub_gs_uniaxaiaal_noCPFE.i) a different exodus output.
Then you can set an execute_on to limit the output to certain times in the simulation.
You can also disable output by some of the subapps by passing command line arguments (Outputs/exodus=false) to certain subapps. This is done in the [MultiApps] block of the main app.
Option 1:
Instead of
[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

you set
[Outputs]
  [exo]
    type = Exodus
    execute_on = FINAL
  []
[]

Option 2:
[MultiApps]
  [sub]
    type = QuadraturePointMultiapp
    input_files = 'sub_gs_uniaxial_noCPFE.i'
    output_in_position = true
    execute_on = timestep_end
    reset_time = '0.02 0.03 0.04 0.05'
    cli_args = 'Outputs/exodus=false' # passed to all of them! otherwise need one param per quadrature point
  []
[]

Hi Guillaume,
Option 2 does not create any of the exodus files at all, which is not the preferred case. Option 1 does seem to limit the formation of outputs, except for the first reset_time. This also requires execute_on = FINAL to be set at the sub-app output block. One weird thing being that the default outputfiles (e.g.,  main_sub0.e) are not created in this case.
Option: 1

Kind regards,
Arun

Option 1:
you can also create a custom execute_on to output only at given times. Will require coding
Option 2:
yes you will need a really long input of exodus=false/true if you want to customize. You can create that with a python script though

Looks like option 1 seems to be the more relevant one. I will see if i can implement something which can only output the default output files suppressing the other ones for times specified in the 'reset_time" list. I may need to priorities other tasks before taking up this work.
I think there may be a 3rd option leveraging the Controls system. I ll have to check though and I ll report back

so you could use a Control on the Outputs/Exodus block
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/controls/ConditionalFunctionEnableControl.html
based on the value of a Function that is the value of a postprocessor
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/FunctionValuePostprocessor.html
for that postprocessor you would set the value from main app using this:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/transfers/MultiAppReporterTransfer.html
not super straightforward

@abarun22 Have you always been getting the *.e-s002 exodus outputs?  I recently noticed some of these showing up in my simulations that used to only output a single exodus file on the subapp.  Does it output one of these files everytime a reset is hit?

Yes Lynn, i've always been getting these additional exodus outputs whenever
i am resetting my sub-apps through `reset_time` parameter. I recently
enabled this parameter to accept a list of times for which the reset
happens. This triggered a creation of series of files for all the reset
times, that bloated my working directory. Working with Guillaume to find a
solution for this issue, so that only the default 'end of simulation' files
are created.
…

 @abarun22 <https://github.com/abarun22> Have you always been getting the
 *.e-s002 exodus outputs? I recently noticed some of these showing up in my
 simulations that used to only output a single exodus file on the subapp.
 Does it output one of these files everytime a reset is hit?

Ok I think I understand the problem better now. You just want to get rid of the -s002 files. I ll have a look into that. I was just giving general advice into how to reduce the number of exodus files.

Hi Guillaume,
Yes, you would need to specify the 'reset_apps' parameter mandatorily to trigger the app reset, without which it will not be possible. The remedy would be to comment out the part of code that creates these extra files whenever user specifies a number under  'reset_apps'. Probbaly it could be an easy fix.
Kind regards,
Arun
ah you're right. This is troublesome in itself. You could specify a reset_time and have it be completely ignored if you forgot to specify a reset_apps

I fixed that part of the problem in a recent PR (the possibility for a parameter to be ignored)
Once #20269 or something similar is merged we will have the main problem solved too, you wont need to reset the app, just trigger a recover which is lighter

node.title: Reference Points in MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Is there a way to create a reference point in MOOSE which I can use to apply the load for my model?
Thanks in advance.

Hello
Sorry we missed this. Yes you can create a nodeset using this
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/ExtraNodesetGenerator.html
then you should apply the load on that nodeset
Guillaume

node.title: Unable to read exodus file
node.bodyText:
I am using Cubit to mesh a geometry and import exodus '.e' file in MOOSE. But I am getting following error:
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "mesh", of type "FileMesh".
Unable to nodeset ID: -123.
Am I missing something during meshing or importing file in MOOSE?

Hello
I havent seen this error before. Can you share your mesh file? Either here or by email at my address listed on github
Guillaume

Also you should try to use this instead of specifying the mesh directly in the [Mesh] block:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/FileMeshGenerator.html

Hello
There's a lot here, I ll just run through a few:

=================================================================================
No numpy version specified in conda_build_config.yaml.  Falling back to default numpy value of 1.11
Using HIT from /Users/HOKON/projects/moose/framework/contrib/hit
Creating Unity /Users/HOKON/projects/ermine/build/unity_src/materials_Unity.C
Compiling C++ (in opt mode) /Users/HOKON/projects/ermine/build/unity_src/materials_Unity.C...
In file included from /Users/HOKON/projects/ermine/build/unity_src/materials_Unity.C:2:
/Users/HOKON/projects/ermine/src/materials/ExampleMaterial.C:48:5: error: field '_phi_YSZ' will be initialized after field '_initial_Cr_deposition' [-Werror,-Wreorder-ctor]
    _phi_YSZ(coupledValue("phi_YSZ")),


This is because the initialization list in the constructor is not in the same order as the class attributes in the header file

/Users/HOKON/projects/ermine/src/materials/ExampleMaterial.C:71:35: error: invalid operands to binary expression ('const MaterialPropertylibMesh::Real' (aka 'const MaterialProperty') and 'const MaterialPropertylibMesh::Real' (aka 'const MaterialProperty'))
(_SD_init * _x_CrO2OH2^(0.5) * _x_H2O^(0.5) * 2 *
~~~~~~~~ ^ ~~~~~~~~~~

this is because a material property is a class. It s not directly a number. You need to access it at a given index to get a number. So when you are retrieving a material property through getMaterialProperty, you can access it like:
__SD_init[_qp]

but only in the computeQpProperties routine, where _qp is defined.

In file included from /Users/HOKON/projects/ermine/build/unity_src/materials_Unity.C:2:
/Users/HOKON/projects/ermine/src/materials/ExampleMaterial.C:72:82: error: invalid operands to binary expression ('double' and 'const VariableValue' (aka 'const MooseArray'))
sinh(_F * 2 / _R / _T * (-_R * _T / _z / _F * log(7e-21 / _p_O2) - (_phi_LSM - _phi_YSZ)))) *
~~~~~ ^ ~~~~~

same comment but for variableValue. You have to access it at [_qp]

In file included from /Users/HOKON/projects/ermine/build/unity_src/materials_Unity.C:2:
/Users/HOKON/projects/ermine/src/materials/ExampleMaterial.C:73:26: error: use of undeclared identifier '_current_elem_volume'
(_current_elem_volume - _initial_Cr_deposition) * _V_molar_Cr2O3 / _z / _F * (_CrDeposit * _t_step));
^

material properties typically do not depend on the element volumes. Materials dont really depend on the mesh usually. So this attribute probably does not exist for materials.
You can still retrieve it through the pointer to the element _current_elem.
See the doxygen for elements:
https://libmesh.github.io/doxygen/classlibMesh_1_1Elem.html
and the volume() routine.
any news on this?

node.title: Example problem with Newton-Raphson
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE Experts
I am working with some non-linear equations which I need to solve using the Newton-Raphson procedure. I just want to know if there is any example equation (should have kernels) that is solved using the Newton Raphson method. Thank you very much.
Best
Avtar

Hello
Sorry we missed this.
Just set solve_type = 'NEWTON' in your executioner.
see https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/executioners/Steady.html
Guillaume

node.title: Composition Gradient - Material Property Gradient
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I'm currently working on a phase separation problem and I need to use the x component of the gradient of the composition. I've been trying to use a DerivativeParsedMaterial to generate the x derivative, but this just outputs zero.
[dc2dx_mat]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    f_name = dc2dx_mat
    material_property_names = 'dc2dx:=D[c2,x]'
    function = 'dc2dx'
    outputs = exodus
    derivative_order = 2
  []

The SplitCHParsed kernel is used to generate the values of c2.
 [c2_res]
    type = SplitCHParsed
    variable = c2
    f_name = F_sum
    kappa_name = kappa_c
    w = w2
    args = 'c3'
  []

Thank you for any help you can offer.

Hello
I'm not sure we can use the DerivativeParsedMaterial for a gradient, unless maybe we define 'x' to be a material property. @dschwen will know
I'd just use this to get the gradient component.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/VariableGradientComponent.html
Guillaume

Thank you for your response and sorry it took me so long to reply.
I've tried using VariableGradientComponent, but I get this error: "nodal variables do not have gradients". I'm not sure what makes c2 a nodal variable.

A nodal variable is defined by its value at nodes.
the issue here is that the shape function derivatives are discontinuous at nodes, so the gradient is not well defined
You should project the variable to an elemental one, then get the gradient of that variable. It wont be exact though. Is this just for postprocessing?
I need to use the gradient to calculate the demagnetizing field.
Which shape function family and order are you using? Note that linear Lagrange doesn't support a second derivative.

Thank you so much for responding, I'm sorry it took me this long to reply.
I've tried using first and second order Lagrange, both gave the same output of zero. I also tried using the Hermite family and got a segmentation fault. What function family would you recommend using for this application?

See #20628 and #18674 for more discussion on this.
Top solutions for short:

use functor material properties instead of regular material properties
OR
write the gradient by deriving it yourself, defining a new material property

node.title: Please take care with your doco
node.bodyText:
Most of you are better coders and designers than i'll ever be, but please take lots of care and time with your documentation.  This is especially important in framework objects, because "modules" classes tend to be documented from a user's perspective, so are generally easy to understand (but not always).  Please take care to use well-written and explanatory english, not things like params.addParam<Real>("coef", 1, "The coefficient");.  Please take care to provide well-written markdown documentation, not just barely-filled stubs like
!syntax description blah
!syntax parameters blah
!syntax inputs blah
!syntax children blah

Please include examples so users don't have to trawl the test files.

Fully agree with this and have been improving the framework doco continuously along with others.
Going to mark this as closed even though this is an always ongoing effort, just to make it easier to find un-answered topics.

node.title: Conda Package and MOOSE libMesh Submodule Update
node.bodyText:
We bumped the minimum Mac OSX SDK to 10.12 and updated our libMesh submodule. The libMesh update was primarily to fix a valgrind error related to Exodus 8. A changelog of the libmesh changes can be found at #20650. To get these changes please use the command:
mamba update --all

If an update is not achieved, please create a new moose conda environment using our Getting Started instructions.
If using the libMesh submodule, please run the update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh script. If any issues are experienced with these updates, please open a new Discussion post. Thanks all!
